Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Frontiers in coding for cloud storage systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cloud storage systems increasingly form the backbone of software services that underwrite everyday lives, serving a large array of businesses and forming an essential pillar of the economy. Given the sheer volume of interactions within these distributed systems, there arise a multitude of issues in building, maintaining and enhancing them. The most salient of these challenges are in the reliability, availability, consistency, confidentiality and privacy of data stored in these vast systems.

The proposed research is expected to have a significant impact on the manner in which cloud storage systems are designed and deployed. In these systems, storage node failures can have a significant impact on the efficiency of the overall system. This project enhances fault tolerant mechanisms to enable efficient recovery from failures, while augmenting the overall data availability and privacy offered by such systems. The research effort will advance the science of cloud computing by developing a new family of algorithms for distributed storage , and connect the advances to the significant industry needs in this topic. The research agenda will also be tightly integrated with education and outreach activities with direct involvement of underrepresented minorities, graduate, and undergraduate students.

Focusing on efficient maintenance of data with a range of desirable qualities, including mechanisms that ease data encoding, accessibility, updates, as well as privacy, the main objectives of this effort include (i) to develop coding schemes where a failed element can be regenerated with higher repair efficiencies from its local neighbors, (ii) to bring together the advantages of both local decodability and local repairability into one coding solution, (iii) to design mechanisms that provide low cost data updates in addition to efficient repair, (iv) to develop codes that can be resilient against failures with different scales/modalities, (v) to develop coding mechanisms taking advantage of implementation aspects of existing systems, and (vi) to develop coding schemes that enable users to access their data in a private manner. This effort addresses these challenges using a combination of tools from disciplines spanning coding theory, information theory, communications, as well as combinatorial and discrete mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today huge amounts of valuable data are routinely stored and retrieved from the cloud every second. It is of paramount importance to protect this data from irrecoverable loss, for example in the event of catastrophic crashes of multiple storage servers rendering their data inaccessible. Error-correcting codes introduce judicious redundancy into the data ensuring that it can be correctly recovered from such failures. While error-correcting codes have been studied since the mid 20th century, their adoption in cloud storage poses new demands on their performance. Since it is commonplace for single (or a few) servers to fail or become temporarily unavailable, the codes must allow for very efficient repair of a small number of erased symbols. Traditional codes such as Reed-Solomon codes that are commonplace in disks and other storage media achieve optimal resilience against erasures for a given level of redundancy. They are, however, not optimized for the efficient repair of a single or few lost symbols. At the other end of the spectrum, simple repetition codes offer easy and efficient repair of a lost symbol from its copies, but suffer from high redundancy and poor resilience to multiple failures.

The thrust of this project was the design of codes that allow for efficient repair of few symbols while at the same time offering excellent global fault-tolerance. Over the last decade, two distinct approaches have been developed towards this goal, each optimizing a different measure of repair efficiency. Locally repairable codes achieve local repair of lost symbols, based on few other symbols. Regenerating codes allow contacting many symbols for recovery, but optimize for repair bandwidth, which is the total amount of information downloaded from other symbols during the repair process. The project gave novel constructions with state-of-the-art parameters of both these kinds of codes. In the process, it introduced new sophisticated algebraic techniques into this domain. The project also established results showing non-trivial limitations of the trade-offs achievable by these codes, breaking significant new ground in this regard and answering longstanding open questions.

For broader impact, the research and outreach activities associated with the project enhanced the cross-fertilization of ideas between information theorists and computer scientists on various aspects related to coding for distributed storage. Various synergistic activities, seminar talks, and continued writing of a textbook on essential coding theory, also accompanied the research goals of the project. The project trained and mentored several graduate students, provided a stimulating research environment for them, and led to high quality Ph.D. dissertations, thereby paving a career path for the students in research and education. The project also formed the basis of some highly successful undergraduate research experiences, leading to publications by undergraduates at the most selective venues of the field and placing them in top Ph.D. programs.
